http://hl7.org/fhir/ValueSet/address-use to
http://hl7.org/fhir/ValueSet/v3-AddressUse

DRAFT (not intended for production usage). Published on Jun 13, 2012 by HL7, Inc (FHIR project team (example):
http://hl7.org/fhir; ). Creative Commons 0
A mapping between the FHIR and HL7 v3 AddressUse Code systems

tr.td: In the HL7 v3 AD, old is handled by the usablePeriod element, but you have to provide a time, there's no simple equivalent of flagging an address as old

description.value: A mapping between the FHIR and HL7 v3 AddressUse Code systems

purpose.value: To help implementers map from HL7 v3/CDA to FHIR

comments.value: In the HL7 v3 AD, old is handled by the usablePeriod element, but you have to provide a time, there's no simple equivalent of flagging an address as old

div.h2: SNOMED CT to ICD-10-CM mappings for fracture of ulna (http://hl7.org/fhir/ConceptMap/103)
div.p: Mapping from http://snomed.info/id?fhir_vs to http://hl7.org/fhir/sid/icd-10-us

DRAFT (not intended for production usage). Published on Jun 13, 2012 by HL7, Inc (FHIR project team (example):
http://hl7.org/fhir; ). Creative Commons 0
Example rule-based mappings between SNOMED CT to ICD-10-CM for fracture of ulna

tr.td: The target mapping to ICD-10-CM is narrower, since additional patient data on the encounter (initial vs. subsequent) and fracture type is required for a valid ICD-10-CM mapping.

The target mapping to ICD-10-CM is narrower, since additional patient data on the encounter (initial vs. subsequent), fracture type and healing (for subsequent encounter) is required for a valid ICD-10-CM mapping.

name.value: SNOMED CT to ICD-10-CM mappings for fracture of ulna

description.value: Example rule-based mappings between SNOMED CT to ICD-10-CM for fracture of ulna

comments.value: The target mapping to ICD-10-CM is narrower, since additional patient data on the encounter (initial vs. subsequent) and fracture type is required for a valid ICD-10-CM mapping.

The target mapping to ICD-10-CM is narrower, since additional patient data on the encounter (initial vs. subsequent), fracture type and healing (for subsequent encounter) is required for a valid ICD-10-CM mapping.

div.h2: Specimen mapping from v2 table 0487 to SNOMED CT (http://hl7.org/fhir/ConceptMap/102)
div.p:
Mapping from
http://hl7.org/fhir/ValueSet/v2-0487 to http://snomed.info/id?fhir_vs

DRAFT. Published on Jul 25, 2013 by FHIR project team (original source: LabMCoP) (
http://hl7.org/fhir; ,
http://www.phconnect.org/group...; ).

tr.td: HL7 term is a historical term. mapped to Pus

This really is not a specimen per se - it is the state of the subject from whom the specimen is collected, so it should be used as a specimen type modifier ONLY!. Often this is indicated with a special medical record number or other notation on the patient. needs to have specimen type (e.g. SPM-4) and source site (SPM.8) and spatial orientation (SPM.9)
submitted (PLR155) with parent of 167874004^knee joint synovial fluid (specimen), with specimen source topography 32361000^Popliteal fossa structure (body structure)
Submit for new term with parent 119365002
Don't use this term for human samples - use Stool instead. animal would use small intestinal contents, large intestinal contents
Submit for new term with parent 119365002
Be more specific use either: 119326000^hair specimen or 119327009^nail specimen
399713008 (Specimen from uterine cervix obtained by cone biopsy (specimen))
submit for new term with parent 119365002^Specimen from wound (specimen)

Prefer to have aspirate of the pus oozing out from cleaned insertion site - if swab is all that can be obtained, then swab after cleaning, otherwise you may get a contaminated specimen and a falsely identified infected central line. Do not just swab the reddened area - that will just collect skin flora
TBD - may use blood and SPM-6
Submit for new term with parent 119365002
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead: not an acceptable specimen for micro - not specific enough term
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
this term is not specific enough, choose from terms that more accurately describe the specimen
Further describe the sample as tissue or pus. or by the collection method. The term boil is not specifc to a body site - need to indicate source site (spm.8). preferred term is Aspirate_Boil
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
Submit for new term with parent 119365002
Submit for new term with parent 119365002
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead: stool is what is expected, should use stool sample
This describes a morphologic abnormality, not a sample
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead: stool is what is expected, should use stool sample
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
should be more specific what kind of lesion is observed - be more specific is it a wound, abscess, mass - specify! Ask SNOMED CT to mark it as a grouper term only (309049000)
The HL7 term is a historical term Mapped to CSF obtained by lumbar puncture
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
be more precise use ulcer, tumor, vesicle
need to know what kind of lesion, so map to: UlcerTissue_penile, VesicleFluid_penile, Wound_penile, Mass tissue_penile, Necrotic tissue_penile, AbscessAspirate_penile, Anything else?
Historical term -though in this case more often used for discharge
Submit for new term with parent: 119365002
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead: stool is what is expected, should use stool sample
Preferred is aspiration with sterile syringe from inflamed area. Specify body location of shunt site
446861007 (Cerebrospinal fluid specimen obtained via ventriculoperitoneal shunt (specimen))
446860008 (Collection of cerebrospinal fluid via ventriculoperitoneal shunt (procedure))
258609006 (Sputum specimen obtained by aspiration from trachea)
446562005 (Body fluid specimen obtained via sump drain (specimen))
Historical term - consider what is being drained and indicate that in SPM-4 instead
122877000 (Upper respiratory fluid specimen obtained by tracheal aspiration (specimen))
This is the name of a lab test. A skin sample is examined for viral inclusions.
122880004 (Urine specimen obtained by clean catch procedure (specimen))
446846006 (Urine specimen obtained via indwelling urinary catheter (specimen))
446277003 (Urine specimen obtained from nephrostomy tube after percutaneous insertion (specimen))
122609004 (Specimen from lung obtained by bronchial washing procedure (specimen))
Bloodbanking term ONLY now map to blood and the respective preservative

Prefer to have aspirate of the pus oozing out from cleaned insertion site - if swab is all that can be obtained, then swab after cleaning, otherwise you may get a contaminated specimen and a falsely identified infected central line. Do not just swab the reddened area - that will just collect skin flora
Be more specific use either: 119326000^hair specimen, or 119327009^nail specimen

assume swab from shunt site for mapping here - clean surface of skin prior to expressing the shunt site - preferred is aspiration with sterile syringe should use SPM.8 to specify body approximate match location of shunt site
